titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. Went this morning to the Catholic Church to hear the obsequies of the late king of Poland, the Elector’s Grandfather, performed— I suppose it an annual solemnity upon the anniversary of his death— The church was partly hung with black; and the Elector with his family and Court appeared in mourning.
The music was very good— Called afterwards on Count Brühl, but did not find him.— Walk with Mrs: A—overtaken by a shower— Towards Evening walked alone— Countess Werthern and her daughter paid a visit to Mrs: A. Mrs: Fylidtzch, Mr: and Mrs: Errington at tea; and Mr: Artaud, who likewise passed the evening with us, and told us much of his travels and adventures in Italy.

2. We went this morning, with the intention to see the Cabinet of Antiques at the Japanese Palace. But the inspector being out of town we were obliged to defer the sight, for another day— We saw the magazine of porcellain from the manufacture at Meissen, which is not equal to that of Berlin. And after that we saw the collection of models in plaister of Paris taken from all the finest antique Statues. The collection was made by Mengs, and is larger than any I have seen before.— There are likewise some of the models, from works of modern sculptors; Michael-Angelo, Bernini, Fiamingo &c. In the evening we went to the Italian Opera, which opens this night for the season. They perform three nights a week, through the Season; chiefly comic Operas. This evening it was Le donne Cambiate, or the Ladies metamorphosed—exactly the story of the English farce called the devil to pay.— The performers are in general good, and as well as the music, so much superior to any thing that I have heard for years, that I was very much delighted with the entertainment.— Mrs: A. went with Mrs: Elliot.

3. We went with Mr: and Mrs: Errington to Königstein— Took four horses with our own carriage, and set out at 7. in the morning. Shortly before 11. we reached the bottom of the rock. By land, it is only three German miles distant from Dresden; and the road, being through Pirna is very good. We went over the whole fortress and saw the Arsenal, the Casemates built by the present elector to lodge the soldiers in time of War; the great tun, full of wine; containing as they told us 10,000 hogsheads— The famous Page’s bed; being a ledge not more than a foot wide upon the summit of the rock; from which the perpendicular descent is about 2000 feet: upon which a certain Page, named Robert von Grünau, once being drunk laid himself down and went to sleep. He was saved by passing a band round him while he slept and drawing him into the window out of which he had crept to take his pleasant siesta— Had he waked of his own accord, he could not possibly have risen, and had he moved himself the space of two inches he must have gone over the ledge— This man, they told us lived to the age of 108 years, having escaped one other danger, nearly as great as that at this spot— A horse upon which he was riding, leapt with him from the bridge at Dresden into the Elbe.— Perhaps the greatest curiosity here however is the great well, dug through the rock, more than 1800 feet deep— A work of forty years. They sent down four lighted candles with one of the buckets to shew the depth more clearly. The buckets are drawn up and down, by a large wheel turned by four men, who are thus constantly employed in drawing water for all the purposes of the garrison.— This fortress is inaccessible excepting at one entrance which is sufficiently guarded by out-works, a draw bridge, a covered way, masked batteries, three gates, and every other proper precaution— A garrison of eight hundred men is sufficient to defend it, and it cannot contain more than 1800— During the seven years war, while the whole electorate was in the possession of the king of Prussia, the Electors family, will all the precious things he had at Dresden, were protected and preserved in this fortress; which Frederic never attacked.— At two in the afternoon, we returned to the inn, and dined, after which we came back to Dresden, and arrived, at about half past seven in the Evening.

4. At 11 this morning we went to see the collection of antiques belonging to the Elector, and kept on the ground floor of the Japanese palace. The number of fragments is very considerable, and of various merit; but most of them have been repaired in modern times, that is about a century ago, at Rome, and the repairs are so indifferently executed that they always injure the remains of the original itself. There are many objects of curiosity in this collection; but none superior to three statues of females almost entire, and the very
same which were first found at Herculanum, and lead to the discovery of the place— One of them, representing a walking vestal, is one of the finest statues I ever saw.— There are likewise several mummies in perfect preservation; the same, mentioned by Pietro de la Valla.— A number of funereal urns still containing their ashes—a couple of lions of Egyptian sculpture at the earliest period of the art, and a Grecian tripod nearly three thousand years old.— We wished to see the medals, but the inspector who attended us, professor Becker told us he could not shew them without an express order from Count Marcolini.— Finished reading Troilus and Cressida, this evening.

5. Called in the morning at Mr: Gregorie’s, but was obliged to defer the purpose of my visit untill monday, the day after to-morrow.— At twelve we went to see the Rüstkammer, or electoral collection of arms ancient and modern, a collection rather large than remarkably curious. Among the rest are preserved here, all the dresses used at a splendid tournament or carousel, given by the elector Augustus 2. in the year 1719 as an entertainment to the king of Denmark.— As there are many of the armours worn formerly by the electors we had opportunity to observe how very heavy they are. A complete armour must have weighed from 150 to 200 pounds.— We were also shewn the barrel of a pistol, being the identical instrument first contrived by Schwartz the inventor of gun powder, to shoot it off— In the afternoon I called at Mr: Elliot’s but he was not at home— Evening at Mr: Errington’s; and jointly with him read three Acts of Hamlet.

6. At noon attended the Court; was presented for the first time to prince Antony the elector’s eldest brother, and also to the electors himself and the other Princes, to take leave— The Electress holds her Court, from 6 to 8 in the evening; but as Mr: Elliot does not go this evening, I must dispense with a presentation for taking leave, to her.— At this Court were the Duke del Parque, a Spanish nobleman appointed as Ambassador to St: Petersbourg some time ago; but who had not reached that post when the Emperor of Russia declared war against Spain; the Duke of Holstein-Beck; a nephew of the Princess who resides at Berlin; and the Count de Lodrone, who is going as Austrian Minister to Stockholm— The two latter staid to dinner.— Had some conversation at dinner with the Count de Bose, who is director of the theatres; he said the Elector would not permit such a play as Kotzebue’s Benjowsky to be performed here on account of its immorality.— Mr: and Mrs: Errington spent the evening with us, and we finished reading Hamlet—

7. Went with Mrs: Adams this forenoon to purchase some bed and table linen; articles which are much cheaper here than at Berlin— Spent the Evening and supped at Mr: Greatheed’s— Played back-gammon with him— I called in the morning upon Mr: Gregory the banker, and drew upon Amsterdam— Met Mr: Hunter there who was going immediately to Leipzig.

8. Greatest part of the day spent in preparing for our departure— Went in the afternoon and paid a visit to Baron Broekhausen, the Prussian Minister— Afterwards spent an hour at Mr: Elliot’s, where we found considerable company.— Remainder of the Evening with Mr: & Mrs: Errington. Had an invitation to dine on Thursday with the Governor von Reitzenstein, which I could not accept, as we are to go, to-morrow— Received several letters—

9. The boasted punctuality of Dresden post-men was this time in default: we had ordered our horses at 4 in the morning, and were then ready for them— They did not come untill past five. We immediately Set out and went to Grossen-Hayn, 4 German miles; we arrived there at half past ten, and after waiting an hour again for horses, proceeded to Cosdorf, 3 miles— We arrived there shortly before three. Dined
while the horses were getting ready, and at four departed again.— At 7. we reached Herzberg two miles, and found very good lodging at the Post-house.— We have thus travelled this day nine German miles, which we have never done before— The road from Dresden as far as Cosdorf is perfectly good; after which we begin again to find them sandy.— We took this road, in order to go through Potsdam.

10. At five this morning we left Herzberg, and went four miles to Jüterbok; where owing to the badness of the roads (sand and mud) we did not arrive untill near noon. At one, afternoon we again set out and reached Beliz, at six; the distance is three miles. They kept us waiting here two hours for horses— Belitz is the first Prussian town; and the boundaries are just before the entrance of the town. We went two miles further in the Evening, and reached Potsdam at half past eleven— We lodge at Henschel’s—the sign of the hermit.

11. We went this morning and saw the gallery of pictures at Sans-souci. It is small but valuable for many excellent pictures— In the afternoon and evening Mrs: Adams was extremely ill with an head-ache— I took a short walk.— I expected Mr: Artaud this Evening, but he did not come.

12. We went this morning to see the Pfauen-insel, or island of Peacocks, a small island in the Havel about 4 English miles below Potsdam; where the late king used to be fond of going by Water; and where he built and furnished a very neat and elegant small pleasure house, for a resting place— At the other end of the island (which is little more than half a miles long) is a farm-house and barn, built to resemble externally a church of Gothic Architecture.— We returned to Potsdam soon after one; dined, and immediately after sat out for Berlin— We reached home at about six o’clock; just before dark, and found Mr: Richards at our door, to welcome our return.
13. Doctor and Mrs: Brown called to see us this forenoon— Walked in the park.— Spent the Evening at Dr: Brown’s— Played chess with him.— We called in the afternoon at Count Golowkin’s.

14. Weather again bad so that I could not go out, all day. Went to the play— Saw the Vinegar Merchant a translation from the french of Mercier; and a farce, called Die Entdeckung—The discovery. Spent an hour afterwards at the Casino.— The Queen has this day a second daughter.
15. Another rainy day throughout.— Wrote all the forenoon.— Countess Pauline Neale spent the Evening with Mrs: Adams
16. Bad weather continues.— Mr: Artaud and Mr: Thompson called to pay us a visit.— Was at the Casino, before dinner.— Spent the Evening again at Doctor Brown’s— Saw Mr: Garlike there.

17. Called this morning at Mr: Schickler’s— Walked under the lime-trees, about an hour.— Mr: Artaud, Mr: Thomson, and Mr: Garlike dined with us— Played Chess after dinner with Garlike— The two youngest Miss Brown’s spent the Evening with us.

18. Reading this morning early, Winckelmann’s history of antient Art.— Evening at the play, and saw Hamlet, in a new translation by Schlegel— The translation is almost litteral; and all the variations of the original of prose, blank verse, and rhyme, are faithfully rendered in the same manner— The whole play was acted; without any of the omissions usual upon the English stage. The only parts well performed were those of Polonius, and the grave-diggers.— Iffland is the best Polonius I ever saw. Madame Unzelmann in Ophelia would have done very well; had she sung all the couplets belonging to the character; instead of which she spoke them all but one or two— Hamlet was performed, not well, by Beschort: Laertes miserably by Schwabke, and the king was so far beneath all censure, that even the patience and good nature of a German Audience, could not forbear hissing him.— Garlike sent me this Evening Mlle: Clairon’s memoirs, and Sir Joshua Reynolds’s discourses to read.
19. Called this afternoon to see the English Prince Augustus, and afterwards Mr: Arbuthnot.— Evening at Dr: Brown’s— Mr: Perponcher and Mr: Courtois there.— Spent an hour at the Casino.
20. Walk in the park before dinner.— Mr: Arbuthnot called and spent an hour with us in the Evening.— Reading Sir Joshua Reynolds’s discourses, and the Memoirs of Mlle: Clairon—

21. Continue to read Winckelmann’s History of antient Art, Mlle: Clairon’s Memoirs and Sir Joshua Reynolds’s discourses. Spent the forenoon in writing, excepting the frequent interruptions.— I am endeavouring to put some order in the arrangement of my library; a task of some difficulty, as that of keeping order in it is more than I ever could attain.

22. My time at present is in general spent at home, with the single exception of an hour before dinner, to walk in the park— The two eldest Miss Brown’s spent an hour with us this Evening.— Finished the volume of Sir Joshua Reynolds’s discourses— We went to the play, but found the house so full that we could get no comfortable seats and therefore returned home.

23. Mr: Garlike called and spent a couple of hours with me this evening; played chess with him— Went afterwards to Doctor Brown’s, where I found Mr: Arbuthnot— Finished reading the Memoirs of Mlle: Clairon.
24. Dined and spent the Evening at Dr: Brown’s— Played Chess with him, and with Mr: Garlike— Letters this Evening from Mr: King, and Mr: Pitcairn
25. Day at home— Somewhat idly spent— Mrs: Adams went to Charlottenburg this forenoon— In the Evening I read a couple of Acts of Shakespear’s Timon of Athens.

26. Mr: Eyssenhardt called upon me this forenoon.— Idle again.— Read in the Evening to Mrs: Adams, in Chaucer: the Clerk’s tale— Taken as the author says, from Petrarch; and likewise a part of the Merchant’s tale. Reading in German, the third volume of Zimmermann’s anecdotes concerning Frederic the great.

27. Finished reading Zimmermann’s anecdotes, and Wieland’s Musarion— Read also the seventh book of his Oberon.— Mrs: Adams went to Charlottenburg this morning.— In the Evening, at Dr: Brown’s. Baron Alvensleben, and Mr: Arbuthnot were there.
28. Read a German Comedy by Grossmann—“Nicht mehr als sechs Schüsseln”—and in the Evening the eighth book of Oberon— Mrs: Adams went with the Miss Brown’s to a concert given by Steibelt—

29. Mrs: A. had a very bad night— Took cold at the concert, and is this day unwell— Young Mr: Schickler called, this forenoon and asked me to dine with his father, who is in town for a few days. Was this Evening at a concert given by Mr: Cohen— Steibelt played upon the Piano Forte, admirably well, and his wife upon the Tambourine— A Lady by the name of Paravicini upon the Violin.— The company was numerous. Mrs: Adams was too unwell to go.— I came away at half past ten— Before supper—

30. Mr: Schickler the Son called this forenoon, and invited me to dine with his father, who has come to spend a few days in town.— I went accordingly— Met there the Jacobin Prince Reuss, who talked with me much about America; of which he knew more than any man I have met in Germany— A Count de Meuron; formerly General of the Dutch troops at the Cape of Good Hope, and now in the English service— He insisted upon it that Massena, in the late affairs had shewn no talents as a Great General— Prince Reuss contended that Suworow was no General— Such is the Spirit of faction— Evening at home.

31. Mr: Catel at 8 o’clock this morning— With him I am resuming the study of German— Read in Chaucer the remainder of the Merchant’s, and the fragment of the Squire’s tale— Wieland is mistaken in supposing that Chaucer calls Oberon and Titania king and queen of the fairies— Chaucer’s names are Pluto & Proserpine; Pope leaves out the names entirely.— The Miss Brown’s spent part of the Evening with us.
